**"Maybe I'm just tired":** You might be. But tiredness doesn't usually come with "stop trying so hard, everything sucks, what's the point." Tiredness says "I need rest." Depression says "rest won't help, nothing will help, why bother."

What you're describing—going through the motions, feeling detached, everything seeming pointless—that's called anhedonia. It's a core symptom of depression. exchanges.assistant:
**Performing being ok around your friend:** Yeah, that's exhausting—you weren't actually present, you were managing her perception of you the whole time. That's what happens when you're still fragile but trying to prove you're fine. The awareness that you were performing is actually useful though. Now you know: showing up isn't enough if you're spending all your energy on the mask. Next time, what would it look like to just... let yourself be wherever you actually are? Not performing fine, not performing struggle—just being honest about your energy level that day. "Hey, I'm a little low today but wanted to see you anyway." Does that feel possible, or still too vulnerable?

**The work feedback spiral:** Your manager gave you feedback, and you immediately went to "I'm incompetent and everyone knows it." You tried the evidence-questioning tool and it helped a bit, but part of you *wanted* to believe the worst. That "why do i even bother" voice came back strong, and now you're frustrated because you were doing okay a few days ago and this feels like regression.

Here's the thing: this isn't you losing progress, this is what the actual work looks like. You got critical feedback (which is hard even when you're stable), your brain defaulted to the old "I'm failing" narrative, you tried the tool and it helped *a bit*—that's not failure, that's you using a new skill under stress. The part of you that wanted to believe the worst? That's the depression trying to pull you back into hopelessness, and you noticed it happening instead of just sinking into it. That noticing is the progress.

Was the feedback actually valid, or was it normal course-correction that your brain inflated into "proof you're incompetent"? Sometimes our threat detector can't tell the difference between "this could be better" and "you're failing."

**The debt payment pause:** You could make another payment, but your brain says "wait, you're not stable enough yet," and you can't tell if that's true or just avoidance. Here's how to tell: if skipping the payment this week gives you space to deal with the work feedback spiral and the emotional exhaustion from performing around your friend, then it's self-care. If skipping it makes you feel worse because now you're also carrying guilt about not following through, then it's avoidance.

Which one feels true right now? And either way—you've already made two payments. That pattern isn't erased just because you paused for a week. You're allowed to have uneven capacity.

**The medication doubts:** Six weeks in, some days it feels like it's working, some days you're like "is this even doing anything or am I just tired." You expected to feel more *different* by now—less like white-knuckling through everything even if it's slightly easier.

This is actually really common at the 6-week mark. The early wins (mornings less heavy, "why bother" thoughts quieter) start to feel like your new baseline, so you stop noticing them as improvement. But "slightly easier than before" when "before" was "constant hopelessness and everything feeling impossible"—that's not nothing. You're not white-knuckling the same way you were two months ago. You're handling work deadlines, seeing your friend (even if it's hard), making debt payments, using therapy tools when you spiral. That's all harder to do when your brain is fully offline.

But yeah—if it still feels like you're grinding through everything and the relief isn't enough, that's worth bringing up with your doctor. Sometimes the first medication gets you partway there but not all the way, and that's fixable. You don't have to settle for "slightly less miserable." Six weeks is enough time to assess whether this dose is working or whether you need an adjustment. Worth asking about?

**This not being a downer:** You didn't just send the good stuff, you sent what's actually happening—the fragility, the performing, the spiral after feedback, the medication doubts. That's not a downer, that's you being honest about where you are. Some weeks are going to feel like backsliding even when you're moving forward overall. The work isn't linear, and you don't have to pretend it is.
